problem.title: Acceleration of an Astronaut by Light Reflected from the Astronaut

statement.p: An astronaut is at a distance of R/4 from the Sun, where R is the average Earth-Sun distance. He holds a perfectly reflecting mirror of area A perpendicular to the rays from the Sun. Find his acceleration due to the radiation pressure alone if his mass along with all the gear is M. Assume that the astronaut is completely behind the mirror so that light strikes the mirror only and the intensity of the sunlight at Earth is I_E.

hint.p: Use F = PA where P is the radiaiton pressure for the case of reflection.

solution.p:
The intensity of the light at the site of the Astronaut will be 4^2\times I_E since the distance from the sun is 1/4^\text{th} of the distance to the Earth. We assume light being incident perpendicularly to the mirror and reflecting off perfectly. Therefore, the radiation force on the mirror + astronaut will be
F = 2\: \dfrac{I}{c}\: A = \dfrac{32 I_E A}{c}.
Using Newton's second law on the mirror + astronaut we find their acceleration solely due to the radiation pressure to be
a = \dfrac{F}{M} = \dfrac{32 I_E A}{Mc}.

problem.title: Placing a Third Polaroid Between two Crossed Polarizers

statement.p: No light passes through two crossed linear polarizers whose axes are 90^\circ to each other. Light however can pass if a third linear polarizer is inserted between the two. What should be the angle the polarizer in the middle should make with the first polarizer so that the intensity of the transmitted light is 5\% of the intensity of unpolarized light incident on the first polarizer.

hint.p: Use Malus's law for the last two polarizers.

solution.p:
Let us denote intensities as follows.
\amp I = \text{starting intensity} \amp I_1 = \text{intensity between first and second polarizers.} \amp I_2 = \text{intensity between second and third polarizers.} \amp I_3 = \text{intensity after third polarizer.}
Now, since the incident light on the first polarizer is unpolarized, we get
I_1 = \frac{1}{2} I.
Let \theta be the direction between first and second polarizer axes. Then, we will have
I_2 = I_1\: \cos^2\theta = \frac{1}{2} I\: \cos^2\theta.
Since first and third polarazers are crossed, meaning their angle is 90^\circ, the angle between second and third will be 90^\circ-\theta. Therefore,
I_3 \amp = I_2\:\cos^2(90^\circ - \theta) = I_2 \sin^2\theta \amp = \frac{1}{2} I\: \cos^2\theta\sin^2\theta = \frac{1}{8} I\: \sin^2(2\theta).
Requiring this be equal to 0.05I gives us a condition on \theta.
\frac{1}{8}\sin^2(2\theta) = 0.05.
Therefore, we get
\theta = \frac{1}{2}\sin^{-1}( \sqrt{ 8\times 0.05} ) = 19.6{\circ}.

problem.title: Intensity of Light Entering Eye when Wearing Polarized Glasses

statement.p: The reflected light from the surface of water (refractive index 4/3) is polarized if the angle of reflection is equal to the Brewster's angle \theta_B. If you are wearing a polaroid glasses whose axis is 80^\circ from horizontal, what is the intensity of light at your eyes if the intensity of the light before reflection from the water surface was 1000\text{ W/m}^2?

hint.p: Use reflectance of S-wave to find I_{r\perp} = R_\perp I_{i\perp} and then use Malus's law.

solution.p:
The light gets polarized upon reflection at the Brewster's angle since P-wave reflection is zero there. Assuming the light before incident had half energy in S-wave and half in P-wave, we see that we need to find the energy reflected in the S-wave only. We will work with reflectance of the S-wave.
R_\perp = \rho_\perp^2 = \left( \frac{n_1\cos\theta_1 - n_2\cos\theta_2 }{n_1\cos\theta_1 + n_2\cos\theta_2}\right)^2,
where we have
n_1 = 1.0,\ n_2 = \frac{4}{3},\ \ \theta_1=\theta_B,\ \ n_2\sin\theta_2=n_1\sin\theta_1.
Once we calculate R_\perp, we can get intensity in the reflected S-wave as
I_{r\perp} = R_\perp I_{i\perp},
where we have assumed that I_{i\perp} = \frac{1}{2}I_0, where I_0=1000\text{ W/m}^2. Now, we have all the pieces and we just calculate.
\amp \theta_B = \tan^{-1}(n_2/n_1) = \tan^{-1}(1.33/1.0) = 53^\circ. \amp \theta_2 = \sin^{-1}(n_1\sin\theta_1/n_2) = 37^\circ. \amp R_\perp = 0.077. \amp I_{r\perp} = 0.077 \times \frac{1000}{2} = 38.5\text{ W/m}^2.
Now the angle between this polarization and the polaroid is 80^\circ. Therefore, by Malus's law, light entering the eye will have intensity
I_\text{into eye} = I_{r\perp}\cos^2 80^\circ = 1.2\text{ W/m}^2.
